title: How is it possible for someone to earn $40,000 in a month from the stories they write on Medium? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m very successful on Medium, which is to say I’ve made over $7,600 from the platform and over $1,000 in a single month. Very, very few people on Medium can say that. And I’m Joe Schmo. I’m a decent writer with broad experience and education. But I’m not internet famous, I’m not a YouTube celebrity, I don’t have a staff writer position for the New Yorker and my dad isn’t a former Navy Seal, retired United States Navy vice admiral and the current Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence. I don’t write tell alls about famous people, I don’t do gossip and I rarely write about Silicon Valley start up secrets, especially nothing that starts with “Seven things startups always do wrong!” My most recent media appearance was BBC World Services radio, talking about high-voltage direct current transmission, which I managed to make sound interesting. Before that I was on Germany’s public broadcaster in their 60 Minutes equivalent for 10 seconds as part of a longer segment on an air carbon capture venture which I’d published a damning report on. Before that, in CBC’s print web site quoted on a hydrogen perpetual energy scam that the New Brunswick government had thrown good money away on. Yeah, HVDC, carbon capture and hydrogen scams. Sexy! My most recent book length non-fiction works are a 150 pp report on global use of machine learning in clean technology, the aforementioned case study of the deeply wrong-headed air carbon capture company and a big report on global blockchain in clean technology uses. Sexy! My podcasting includes 90 minute deep dives with Mark Z. Jacobson on 100% renewables by 2050, 30 minutes with Michael Mann on why we are in bigger climate trouble than we realize, 90 minutes with a cognitive psychologist on patterns of disinformation related to climate change and 90 minutes talking about the future of autonomous delivery vehicles in cities with a PhD on the subject. Oh, and 90 minutes talking to a PhD of economics about behavioral economics. Sexy! Okay, I’m a global energy wonk who may not be Joe Schmo in that tiny niche, but really. My top read Medium stories are: Tesla Is Doing Much Better Than Headlines Suggest - 63,000 reads - Tweeted by Maye Musk, and then her son, whose name you might know, retweeted itWhat does it mean when someone calls you a unicorn? - 41,000 reads - Retweeted by nobody, but it’s awfully cute and very briefConservatives Hate Postmodernism, and Liberals Don’t Understand Why - 37,000 - And why the heck this one went off, I have no idea, but Jordan B. Peterson is one of the people who hates postmodernism while being absurdly inaccurate about it and conflating it with Stalinism, which it’s an opposite of.Jordan Peterson Is Divisive Because of His Weaknesses, Not His Strengths - 30,000 - Peterson was always good clickbait.Jordan Peterson: climate change denier and faux science-lover - 30,000 - And there’s Peterson again.Hmmm… Tesla/ Elon Musk and Jordan B. Peterson. Oh, and unicorns, which does actually have a side helping of Silicon Valley startups in it. Yeah, clickbait. Down at the sank-without-a-trace end: Peak oil is coming but of demand not supply - wonkyBlockchain and immunizations have no adverse effects - wonky and nicheBenign warmists: the next wave of climate change deniers - assessing climate denial driftPatchwork regulation slows low-carbon transformation - wonkyUniversal basic income isn’t universal or basic - very wonkyNotice a difference? And to be clear, I didn’t intentionally write the first five to go off big, I just wrote stuff that was interesting to me that happened to intersect to what people care about. Most of my stuff is equally well written. I do completely adequate writing very rapidly. I don’t agonize over sentences to craft them into the literary equivalents of this hummingbird.  Some of my sentences are, in fact, clunky. Sometimes I fix them. That’s as true of my most viewed pieces as my least.  Want to make $40,000 a month on Medium? Write about celebrities.Write clickbait.Be famous for other reasons and leverage that for this platform.The top 5 by followers on Medium are  Vanerchuk is a serial entrepreneur in a celebrity-focused industry worth an estimated $160 million, and a complete hustler and shmoozer. Williams co-founded Twitter and runs Medium. He’s worth an estimated $2.3 billion. O’Reilly is so entrenched in Silicon Valley and technogeek culture that it’s kind of absurd. O’Reilly Media technical manuals were on every computer nerds’ bookshelf and he coined terms that seem completely ubiquitous today. Clinton. I mean, c’mon. Stone is a co-founder of Twitter and is worth a billion. If they have monetized their Medium accounts, I can pretty much guarantee that they are getting easily $40,000 per month, not that they need it, but it does pay for the occasional sushi dinner for a family of 500, one supposes. #10 on the list? Bernie Sanders.  Yeah, that’s the competition on Medium. And I haven’t even mentioned Tim Wise (follow him, read his stuff) or umair haque with his dystopic and dyspeptic views of the failure of the American experiment. Could I make $40,000 in a month on Medium? Maybe, by being something I’m not, intentionally and with malice. But I’d be bored so quickly I’d probably give up. Medium is something I do in my spare time, something I do as an outlet for certain ideas, something I leave as a bread crumb trail of a subset of my thinking. Like all bread crumb trails, sometimes it allows other people to find me and engage me in interesting conversations. That’s how the PhD economics and senior fellow of the Niskanen Center and I connected, for example. But if you want Medium to be a business, write a lot of short clickbait about celebrities and startups. Expect most of it to fail and some of it to go viral. You’ll make all your money off of the viral, but you’ll also get a long tail of occasional love to your smaller pieces that will be base revenue. Until the platform changes, of course.

response.answer_text: You’d have to write something popular, incredibly popular. Or, on the flip side, write a lot of stories that generate a reasonable amount of traffic. Medium works by paying its writers a percentage of their readers monthly subscription based on the amount of time they spent reading your story. The monthly subscription is $5. Assuming all of this subscription goes to paying the authors of the story(It obviously doesn’t, Medium needs to make money some how) this means you’d need 100% of the view time of 8,000 people. That’s a lot, especially when you consider that this is a very generous estimation, but it’s not impossible. In Septemeber 2020 the highest earning author earnt just shy of $50,000[1] . This is more an exception than the norm, espcially when you consider only 6.4% earnt over $100. The stories generating that much money attract huge amounts of traffic and the authors writing them are pumping out multiple per day. As to how they’re genearting this traffic, that a marketing question. Though the answer is pretty boring. A lot of medium posts are generally higher quality than normal, especially those that are written well, but they’re not free from the general trends of the internet. Clickbait titles genearte clicks and people will usually stick around to see if it’s backed up. Politics, espically that that already agrees with the general views of the demographic using the site get a lot of attention, remember, this is based off reading time, not just clicks. That being said, as long as what you write is interesting and you post often enough to gain traction, there’s a decent amount of money to be made. Footnotes[1] How Much Money Can You Make Writing for Medium?
